newsitem.title: USA: FORECAST-U.S. Dec PPI seen tame, but oil a concern.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-U.S. Dec PPI seen tame, but oil a concern.

text.p: U.S. wholesale prices are expected to show only modest increases for the month of December, though rising energy prices could pose an inflationary threat down the road, economists said on Tuesday.
Experts surveyed by Reuters are calling for a 0.3 percent overall gain in the December Producer Price Index, due from the Labor Department at 0830 EST/1330 GMT on Thursday, January 9.
The core rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, is expected to post a reassuring 0.1 percent rise for December.

"Energy prices will be up in December but only by a small amount," said Christopher Low, senior economist at HSBC Markets Inc, noting that a decline in November crude oil prices could filter through to depressed gasoline prices in the December report.
"But next month will be worse," he added. "People are beginning to realize that the energy price increases we've seen recently are not going to go away."
Forecasts for colder weather in the Northeast have pushed energy prices sharply higher of late, with heating oil leading the way.
And although the heating and crude oil price run took a breather on Tuesday, analysts said sentiment remains bullish.
Low is predicting a modest 0.2 percent rise in both the overall and core producer price rates for December, but sees reason for concern on the energy front going forward.
"Even with reassuring numbers there's a very subtle shift taking place," he said. "I think people will begin discussing the threat of pipeline inflationary pressures within a few months."
David Sloan, senior economist at consulting firm I.D.E.A. Inc, agreed that energy price gains were becoming "something of a worry," but foresaw little reason for concern about the December figures.
He expects a 0.1 percent increase in the headline and core producer price rates and predicts a continuation of last month's slight fall in food prices.
In November producer prices rose 0.4 percent overall and by 0.1 percent excluding food and energy prices.

In the finished goods category, gasoline prices rose by 2.8 percent in November, while passenger car prices gained at a 0.5 percent pace. Heating oil and tobacco products were the only decliners in the category.
In crude goods, energy materials prices including crude petroleum gained at a 7.7 percent pace in November, while crude petroleum prices declined by 4.6 percent.
